stem: A client with AKI has a serum potassium level of 8.2 mEq/L. Based on the documentation in the Nephrology Emergency & EKG Strip Log, which medication should the nurse prioritize administering first?

rationale.correct: The 'Sinusoidal' or Sine-wave EKG (a1) is the final stage of hyperkalemia before cardiac arrest (asystole or V-Fib). When the heart is unstable, the **absolute priority is Calcium Gluconate (a1)**. This medication does NOT lower potassium; instead, it 'antagonizes' the effect of potassium on the cardiac cell membrane, effectively 'stabilizing' the heart to prevent a lethal rhythm. The other meds (Insulin, Albuterol) move potassium into cells, but take 15-30 mins to work—time the client does not have.
clinicalPearls: Calcium for the HEART. Insulin/Dextrose for the BLOOD (lowering K). Kayexalate for the BOWEL (removing K).
Sine-wave = Highest emergency level in hyperkalemia.
Calcium gluconate has a short duration of action (30–60 mins); it is a temporary 'shield' while the other drugs lower the level.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: While true, in an EKG emergency, your goal isn't to fix the 'lab value' first; it's to keep the heart beating. Calcium is the only drug on the list that protects the heart *immediately*.

exhibits.title: Cardiac Monitor Strip
exhibits.content:
Current Visual: Absence of P-waves. Extremely widened, merging QRS complexes creating a 'sine-wave' or sinusoidal appearance. Heart rate 42.
Condition: Client is becoming unresponsive.

exhibits.title: Laboratory Alerts
exhibits.content:
Stat Result: Serum Potassium 8.2 mEq/L.
Previous: 6.4 mEq/L (4 hours ago).

exhibits.title: Hyperkalemia Protocol
exhibits.content:
1. IV Calcium Gluconate (10%) 1 ampule over 5 mins.
2. IV Regular Insulin 10 units with 50 mL D50W.
3. Albuterol 10-20 mg via nebulizer.
4. Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate (Kayexalate) 30g PO/PR.
